Alom", "Aliaksei Narbonau", "Marco Rolando Camelen Min", "Athena M. Soulika", "Michael Levin", "Barge Jonathan", "Marcela Gomez", "Hish Zhao", "Mircea Teodorescu", "Roslyn Rivkah Isseroff"]
file_metadata.title: Programmable Delivery of Fluoxetine via Wearable Bioelectronics for Wound Healing

chunks.text: The ability to deliver drugs with precise dosages at specific time points can significantly improve disease treatment while reducing side effects. Drug encapsulation for gradual delivery has opened the doors for a superior treatment regimen. Programming bioelectronic devices to deliver small molecules enables ad-hoc personalized therapeutic profiles that are more complex than gradual release. Here, a wearable bioelectronic device with an integrated electrophoretic ion pump that affords on-demand drug delivery with precise dose control is introduced. Delivery of fluoxetine to wounds in mice resulted in a 27.2% decrease in the macrophage ratio (M1/M2) and a 39.9% increase in re-epithelialization, indicating a shorter inflammatory phase and faster overall healing. Programmable drug delivery using wearable bioelectronics in wounds introduces a broadly applicable strategy for the long-term delivery of a prescribed treatment regimen with minimal external intervention.
chunks.chunk_summary: A wearable bioelectronic device with an integrated ion pump enables programmable drug delivery, demonstrated by improved wound healing in mice through fluoxetine administration.
chunks.authors: ["Houpu Li", "Hsin-ya Yang", "Narges Assefzadehbabai", "Prabhat Baniva", "Andrea Medina Lopez", "Anthony Gallegos", "Kan Zhu", "Tiffany Nguyen", "Cristian Hernandez", "Ksenia Zlobina", "Cynthia Recendez", "Hao-Chieh Hsieh", "Manyam Tebyan", "Hector Carreon", "John Selberg", "Le Luo", "Moysar A. Alom", "Aliaksei Narbonau", "Marco Rolando Camelen Min", "Athena M. Soulika", "Michael Levin", "Barge Jonathan", "Marcela Gomez", "Hish Zhao", "Mircea Teodorescu", "Roslyn Rivkah Isseroff"]

chunks.text: Tailoring therapeutic drug levels over time improves treatment effectiveness and leads to better clinical outcomes. Research in drug delivery has developed materials and chemical strategies for passively and actively controlled release. Merging active control with programmable electronic devices can enable personalized and more effective treatment regimens. Bioelectronic devices can deliver on-demand physiological-active ions, small molecules, and electric fields as treatments. This ability is particularly important for rapidly changing environments like wounds. Wound healing involves four overlapping phases: hemostasis, inflammation, proliferation, and remodeling. A delay or disruption in any phase can lead to chronicity, scarring, infection, sepsis, and even death. Wearable bioelectronics have employed external stimuli like electric fields and biochemicals to facilitate wound healing. This study developed a programmable bioelectronic device capable of delivering fluoxetine (FLX), a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI), to reduce inflammation and accelerate healing in a mouse wound model. Prior studies have shown that systemic and topical fluoxetine administration improves wound healing in diabetic and non-diabetic rodents, decreases wound pathogen growth, biofilm formation, and infection dissemination.
chunks.chunk_summary: Programmable bioelectronic devices offer precise drug delivery, crucial for dynamic environments like wounds, and this study uses such a device to deliver fluoxetine for accelerated wound healing.
chunks.authors: ["Houpu Li", "Hsin-ya Yang", "Narges Assefzadehbabai", "Prabhat Baniva", "Andrea Medina Lopez", "Anthony Gallegos", "Kan Zhu", "Tiffany Nguyen", "Cristian Hernandez", "Ksenia Zlobina", "Cynthia Recendez", "Hao-Chieh Hsieh", "Manyam Tebyan", "Hector Carreon", "John Selberg", "Le Luo", "Moysar A. Alom", "Aliaksei Narbonau", "Marco Rolando Camelen Min", "Athena M. Soulika", "Michael Levin", "Barge Jonathan", "Marcela Gomez", "Hish Zhao", "Mircea Teodorescu", "Roslyn Rivkah Isseroff"]

chunks.text: The wearable bioelectronic device consists of two modules: an ion pump drug delivery module and a battery-powered controller module. The controller module translates a pre-programmed delivery profile into voltage signals, activating the ion pump to deliver fluoxetine to the wound. The ion pump module has two reservoirs containing a fluoxetine solution, connected to the wound bed through glass capillaries filled with an ion-selective hydrogel. The module is made of PDMS. Two Ag/AgCl electrodes connect the reservoirs to the voltage source, driving fluoxetine delivery using VFLX. The reservoir solution is acidic 0.01 M fluoxetine hydrochloride (FLX-HCl) at pH 6, making fluoxetine positively charged (FLX+). When VFLX is positive, FLX+ is pushed from the reservoir into the wound bed via the ion-selective hydrogel, which blocks anions. Physiological cations exit the wound bed through the hydrogel on the right, maintaining charge neutrality. The concentration difference between physiological cations and fluoxetine ensures minimal fluoxetine escape.
chunks.chunk_summary: The device comprises an ion pump module and a controller module; the ion pump uses an acidic fluoxetine solution and voltage signals to deliver positively charged fluoxetine to the wound bed via an ion-selective hydrogel.
chunks.authors: ["Houpu Li", "Hsin-ya Yang", "Narges Assefzadehbabai", "Prabhat Baniva", "Andrea Medina Lopez", "Anthony Gallegos", "Kan Zhu", "Tiffany Nguyen", "Cristian Hernandez", "Ksenia Zlobina", "Cynthia Recendez", "Hao-Chieh Hsieh", "Manyam Tebyan", "Hector Carreon", "John Selberg", "Le Luo", "Moysar A. Alom", "Aliaksei Narbonau", "Marco Rolando Camelen Min", "Athena M. Soulika", "Michael Levin", "Barge Jonathan", "Marcela Gomez", "Hish Zhao", "Mircea Teodorescu", "Roslyn Rivkah Isseroff"]

chunks.text: Continuous FLX+ delivery is due to electrochemical reactions at the electrodes. At the anode, protonated FLX+ (FLX+Cl-) reacts: an electron leaves Ag, creating Ag+, which reacts with Cl- to form AgCl, freeing FLX+. At the counter electrode, an electron creates Cl- that pairs with a physiological cation (e.g., Na+, K+), leaving an Ag surface and a salt. The ion pump has four reservoirs and four pins connected to the Ag/AgCl electrodes, providing mechanical coupling between modules. Two reservoirs deliver FLX+, while two house reference/counter electrodes. COMSOL simulations show uniform FLX+ distribution on the wound. The control module contains microcontrollers, converters, and a battery for wireless operation. The control electronics translate the delivery regimen into VFLX pulses.
chunks.chunk_summary: Electrochemical reactions at the anode and counter electrode maintain continuous FLX+ delivery; the ion pump module ensures uniform distribution, and the control module manages wireless operation and voltage pulses.
chunks.authors: ["Houpu Li", "Hsin-ya Yang", "Narges Assefzadehbabai", "Prabhat Baniva", "Andrea Medina Lopez", "Anthony Gallegos", "Kan Zhu", "Tiffany Nguyen", "Cristian Hernandez", "Ksenia Zlobina", "Cynthia Recendez", "Hao-Chieh Hsieh", "Manyam Tebyan", "Hector Carreon", "John Selberg", "Le Luo", "Moysar A. Alom", "Aliaksei Narbonau", "Marco Rolando Camelen Min", "Athena M. Soulika", "Michael Levin", "Barge Jonathan", "Marcela Gomez", "Hish Zhao", "Mircea Teodorescu", "Roslyn Rivkah Isseroff"]

chunks.text: The ion pump was tested in a well plate with saline, using a potentiostat. Current (IFLX) was measured during VFLX pulses (0–2 V, 200 ms). IFLX increased linearly with VFLX, proportional to delivered FLX+. HPLC-MS measured FLX+ delivered after pulses. Delivery efficiency (η) was 20 ± 4%, meaning one FLX+ per five electrons. This efficiency is typical for ion pumps. Calculating η allows dose inference from IFLX. In vivo testing used a mouse wound model with a 6 mm punch wound held open by a silicone splint ring to minimize wound contraction. The lightweight device (2.5 g) was affixed with Tegaderm. FLX+ was delivered for three days, six hours per day, targeting 100 nMol daily. A blinking LED indicated successful delivery.
chunks.topic: In vitro and in vivo testing setup
chunks.chunk_summary: In vitro testing showed linear current increase with voltage, and a delivery efficiency of 20%; in vivo testing involved a mouse wound model with a 6 mm wound, a 2.5 g device, and a 100 nMol daily fluoxetine dose for three days.
chunks.authors: ["Houpu Li", "Hsin-ya Yang", "Narges Assefzadehbabai", "Prabhat Baniva", "Andrea Medina Lopez", "Anthony Gallegos", "Kan Zhu", "Tiffany Nguyen", "Cristian Hernandez", "Ksenia Zlobina", "Cynthia Recendez", "Hao-Chieh Hsieh", "Manyam Tebyan", "Hector Carreon", "John Selberg", "Le Luo", "Moysar A. Alom", "Aliaksei Narbonau", "Marco Rolando Camelen Min", "Athena M. Soulika", "Michael Levin", "Barge Jonathan", "Marcela Gomez", "Hish Zhao", "Mircea Teodorescu", "Roslyn Rivkah Isseroff"]

chunks.text: A machine-learning algorithm analyzed wound size and area. Both control and treated wounds slightly increased in size at day 1 and decreased subsequently. There was no significant difference in wound area between groups. Re-epithelialization was measured on excised, fixed, and H&E-stained wounds. FLX+ treatment resulted in a 39.9% (P<0.05) increase in re-epithelialization compared to control, indicating improved early-stage healing. The actual delivered fluoxetine amount was calculated using the correlation between dose and charge in the ion pump. Due to blood flow and drug half-life, direct wound concentration measurement is challenging; however, the ion pump's characteristics allowed dose quantification based on measured current. Across 15 mice, the device consistently delivered the desired dose. Variability was attributed to system factors like contact resistance changes during movement. This variability allowed a qualitative correlation between FLX+ dose and re-epithelialization. Higher doses correlated with faster re-epithelialization, consistent with topical fluoxetine application. A current control system with closed-loop algorithms could improve precision.
chunks.chunk_summary: While wound area showed no significant difference, FLX+ treatment increased re-epithelialization by 39.9%; dose quantification was based on measured current, and higher doses correlated with faster healing, suggesting potential for precision improvement with closed-loop systems.
chunks.authors: ["Houpu Li", "Hsin-ya Yang", "Narges Assefzadehbabai", "Prabhat Baniva", "Andrea Medina Lopez", "Anthony Gallegos", "Kan Zhu", "Tiffany Nguyen", "Cristian Hernandez", "Ksenia Zlobina", "Cynthia Recendez", "Hao-Chieh Hsieh", "Manyam Tebyan", "Hector Carreon", "John Selberg", "Le Luo", "Moysar A. Alom", "Aliaksei Narbonau", "Marco Rolando Camelen Min", "Athena M. Soulika", "Michael Levin", "Barge Jonathan", "Marcela Gomez", "Hish Zhao", "Mircea Teodorescu", "Roslyn Rivkah Isseroff"]

chunks.text: The M1/M2 macrophage ratio, a crucial wound healing indicator, was examined. Macrophages are crucial for immune response and wound healing/regeneration.  A simplified classification defines M1 (pro-inflammatory) and M2 (anti-inflammatory, tissue repair) subtypes. Immunohistochemistry identified M1 macrophages infiltrating the control wound center after three days, with no change in the treated wound. M2-like macrophages increased in the treated wound center. At day 3, the M1/M2 ratio was reduced following treatment. Fluoxetine treatment reduced the day 3 M1/M2 ratio by 27.2% (P<0.05), indicating fewer pro-inflammatory macrophages and faster progression toward the reparative phase, consistent with improved re-epithelialization.
chunks.chunk_summary: Fluoxetine treatment reduced the M1/M2 macrophage ratio by 27.2%, indicating a shift towards anti-inflammatory M2 macrophages and faster progression to the reparative healing phase.
chunks.authors: ["Houpu Li", "Hsin-ya Yang", "Narges Assefzadehbabai", "Prabhat Baniva", "Andrea Medina Lopez", "Anthony Gallegos", "Kan Zhu", "Tiffany Nguyen", "Cristian Hernandez", "Ksenia Zlobina", "Cynthia Recendez", "Hao-Chieh Hsieh", "Manyam Tebyan", "Hector Carreon", "John Selberg", "Le Luo", "Moysar A. Alom", "Aliaksei Narbonau", "Marco Rolando Camelen Min", "Athena M. Soulika", "Michael Levin", "Barge Jonathan", "Marcela Gomez", "Hish Zhao", "Mircea Teodorescu", "Roslyn Rivkah Isseroff"]

chunks.text: The M1/M2 ratio change was examined over the healing process using published time-series data from incisional wounds. While comparing incisional and excisional wound data may be imperfect, it allows wound progression estimation. The day 3 M1/M2 ratios for both groups were similar to the published time-series. Considering other indicators (re-epithelialization, macrophage presence, diminishing wound size), the day 3 data corresponds to the monotonically decreasing M1/M2 phase (days 3-5) of the published curve. A lower M1/M2 ratio indicates a later healing stage. The M1-M2 transition is critical for inflammation resolution and tissue repair. Increased re-epithelialization and decreased M1/M2 ratio in treated wounds demonstrate that the device's fluoxetine treatment accelerated healing, consistent with prior studies.
chunks.chunk_summary: Analysis of the M1/M2 ratio over time suggests that fluoxetine treatment accelerated wound healing by promoting a faster transition to the later stages of healing characterized by a lower M1/M2 ratio.
chunks.authors: ["Houpu Li", "Hsin-ya Yang", "Narges Assefzadehbabai", "Prabhat Baniva", "Andrea Medina Lopez", "Anthony Gallegos", "Kan Zhu", "Tiffany Nguyen", "Cristian Hernandez", "Ksenia Zlobina", "Cynthia Recendez", "Hao-Chieh Hsieh", "Manyam Tebyan", "Hector Carreon", "John Selberg", "Le Luo", "Moysar A. Alom", "Aliaksei Narbonau", "Marco Rolando Camelen Min", "Athena M. Soulika", "Michael Levin", "Barge Jonathan", "Marcela Gomez", "Hish Zhao", "Mircea Teodorescu", "Roslyn Rivkah Isseroff"]

chunks.text: Although fluoxetine is primarily a systemic antidepressant, recent studies identifying serotonin receptors in epidermal cells reveal its potential for wound healing. Topical fluoxetine improves healing in diabetic and non-diabetic rodent skin and minimizes infection, possibly by regulating the local serotonin pathway to promote keratinocyte migration and modulate inflammation. Fluoxetine also increases M2 phenotype in microglial macrophages in vitro. These effects contribute to improved skin wound healing. The wearable device provides continuous treatment, limiting patient error and non-adherence associated with self-delivered topical treatments. It minimizes off-target effects due to minimal systemic fluoxetine accumulation or impact on serotonin metabolism. A 7-day positive control with topical fluoxetine decreased re-epithelialization, while bioelectronic delivery increased it by 39.9% at day 3.  The precise delivery system may enable temporal targeting of specific immune or epithelial cell sub-populations during tissue repair.
chunks.chunk_summary: Fluoxetine's role in wound healing is supported by its interaction with serotonin receptors in epidermal cells, its promotion of keratinocyte migration and M2 macrophage phenotype, and the improved healing observed with bioelectronic delivery compared to topical application.
chunks.authors: ["Houpu Li", "Hsin-ya Yang", "Narges Assefzadehbabai", "Prabhat Baniva", "Andrea Medina Lopez", "Anthony Gallegos", "Kan Zhu", "Tiffany Nguyen", "Cristian Hernandez", "Ksenia Zlobina", "Cynthia Recendez", "Hao-Chieh Hsieh", "Manyam Tebyan", "Hector Carreon", "John Selberg", "Le Luo", "Moysar A. Alom", "Aliaksei Narbonau", "Marco Rolando Camelen Min", "Athena M. Soulika", "Michael Levin", "Barge Jonathan", "Marcela Gomez", "Hish Zhao", "Mircea Teodorescu", "Roslyn Rivkah Isseroff"]

chunks.text: This study is a proof of concept with a small sample size and short treatment duration, resulting in varied outcomes. The device delivered a pre-determined dose repetitively, not a customized regimen. While bioelectronic delivery improved healing compared to no treatment, further studies comparing it to other methods (bolus topical application, gradual release encapsulations) are needed. The device can deliver other charged biomolecules (e.g., acetylcholine) or neutral molecules converted to charged ions (e.g., GABA). Histological staining (re-epithelialization via H&E, macrophage phenotype via immunohistochemistry) was used to monitor healing. More advanced techniques like Imaging Mass Cytometry (IMC) could provide greater detail in future studies. As a proof-of-concept, 34 mice were sacrificed on day 3 for analysis. A larger sample size across various time points would be more conclusive.
chunks.chunk_summary: This proof-of-concept study has limitations in sample size, treatment duration, and delivery regimen; future studies should compare bioelectronic delivery with other methods and explore advanced analysis techniques like IMC.
chunks.authors: ["Houpu Li", "Hsin-ya Yang", "Narges Assefzadehbabai", "Prabhat Baniva", "Andrea Medina Lopez", "Anthony Gallegos", "Kan Zhu", "Tiffany Nguyen", "Cristian Hernandez", "Ksenia Zlobina", "Cynthia Recendez", "Hao-Chieh Hsieh", "Manyam Tebyan", "Hector Carreon", "John Selberg", "Le Luo", "Moysar A. Alom", "Aliaksei Narbonau", "Marco Rolando Camelen Min", "Athena M. Soulika", "Michael Levin", "Barge Jonathan", "Marcela Gomez", "Hish Zhao", "Mircea Teodorescu", "Roslyn Rivkah Isseroff"]

chunks.text: This study demonstrates a wearable bioelectronic device for actively controlling drug release for in vivo wound healing. The standalone device includes an ion pump, controller, and power supply, eliminating external connections. This allows extended use without interaction. The device provided timed, programmed fluoxetine delivery in a mouse wound model, eliminating patient intervention. Treatment resulted in faster healing at day 3 (39.9% increase in re-epithelialization, 27.2% decrease in M1/M2 ratio). This suggests fluoxetine delivery promotes healing by influencing M1/M2 balance and keratinocyte migration. While fluoxetine's healing effect is known, the device offers customized dosing with temporal precision, advantageous over conventional systemic routes. Future research can program release timing to align with wound stage in a closed-loop fashion. The device's design will be further optimized for potential clinical use.
chunks.topic: Summary of findings and future work
chunks.chunk_summary: The wearable bioelectronic device successfully delivered fluoxetine, resulting in faster wound healing in mice; future work will focus on optimizing the device for clinical use and implementing closed-loop, stage-specific drug delivery.
chunks.authors: ["Houpu Li", "Hsin-ya Yang", "Narges Assefzadehbabai", "Prabhat Baniva", "Andrea Medina Lopez", "Anthony Gallegos", "Kan Zhu", "Tiffany Nguyen", "Cristian Hernandez", "Ksenia Zlobina", "Cynthia Recendez", "Hao-Chieh Hsieh", "Manyam Tebyan", "Hector Carreon", "John Selberg", "Le Luo", "Moysar A. Alom", "Aliaksei Narbonau", "Marco Rolando Camelen Min", "Athena M. Soulika", "Michael Levin", "Barge Jonathan", "Marcela Gomez", "Hish Zhao", "Mircea Teodorescu", "Roslyn Rivkah Isseroff"]

chunks.text: This study evaluated a wearable bioelectronic device with an electrophoretic ion pump for programmable drug delivery and enhanced wound healing in mice. The hypothesis was that the device could deliver drugs with precise dose control and personalized therapeutic profiles, leading to faster healing. The device was tested in vivo on 37 male C57BL/6J mice (15 treatment, 22 control). 6 mm wounds were created, and the treatment group received 6 h of fluoxetine delivery per day for 3 days. Wound area, re-epithelialization, and M1/M2 ratio were evaluated. The device comprises a delivery module (ion pump) and a controller module (PCB, electronics, battery).
chunks.chunk_summary: The study evaluated a wearable bioelectronic device for enhanced wound healing in mice by delivering fluoxetine for 6 hours/day over 3 days and assessing wound area, re-epithelialization, and M1/M2 ratio.
chunks.authors: ["Houpu Li", "Hsin-ya Yang", "Narges Assefzadehbabai", "Prabhat Baniva", "Andrea Medina Lopez", "Anthony Gallegos", "Kan Zhu", "Tiffany Nguyen", "Cristian Hernandez", "Ksenia Zlobina", "Cynthia Recendez", "Hao-Chieh Hsieh", "Manyam Tebyan", "Hector Carreon", "John Selberg", "Le Luo", "Moysar A. Alom", "Aliaksei Narbonau", "Marco Rolando Camelen Min", "Athena M. Soulika", "Michael Levin", "Barge Jonathan", "Marcela Gomez", "Hish Zhao", "Mircea Teodorescu", "Roslyn Rivkah Isseroff"]

chunks.text: The ion pump was fabricated using 3D-printed, two-part PDMS molds. The PDMS parts were cleaned and assembled. The top layer contained four reservoirs for fluoxetine and four hydrogel-filled capillaries for delivery. The bottom layer acted as a lid with a notch for wound contact. Ag/AgCl wires were inserted into each reservoir. The layers were bonded using oxygen plasma treatment and aluminum pieces. Parylene coating increased media lifetime. Hydrogel-filled capillaries (ion exchange membrane) were fabricated using 1 M AMPSA, 0.4 M PEGDA, and 0.05 M photoinitiator. 100 mm silica tubing was etched and treated with silane A174. The hydrogel was UV-cured, segmented, and loaded with 0.01 M fluoxetine. The capillaries were inserted into reservoirs.
chunks.chunk_summary: The ion pump was fabricated using PDMS molds, Ag/AgCl wires, hydrogel-filled capillaries acting as an ion exchange membrane, and Parylene coating for increased media lifetime.
chunks.authors: ["Houpu Li", "Hsin-ya Yang", "Narges Assefzadehbabai", "Prabhat Baniva", "Andrea Medina Lopez", "Anthony Gallegos", "Kan Zhu", "Tiffany Nguyen", "Cristian Hernandez", "Ksenia Zlobina", "Cynthia Recendez", "Hao-Chieh Hsieh", "Manyam Tebyan", "Hector Carreon", "John Selberg", "Le Luo", "Moysar A. Alom", "Aliaksei Narbonau", "Marco Rolando Camelen Min", "Athena M. Soulika", "Michael Levin", "Barge Jonathan", "Marcela Gomez", "Hish Zhao", "Mircea Teodorescu", "Roslyn Rivkah Isseroff"]

chunks.text: The controller module includes a programmable PCB with electronics for actuation and sensing. The PCB contains a microcontroller with ADC, memory, DAC, and resistors for current sensing. Programs were flashed into the microcontroller, and actuation started upon battery insertion. The microcontroller sent I2C commands to the DAC to apply voltages to the ion pump electrodes. Current flow through resistors generated voltages read by the ADC or external probes. Steel pins were inserted into the ion pump's PDMS layer and coated with silver paste for electrical connections. The pins were soldered to the PCB. Sterilized 0.01 M fluoxetine hydrochloride (pH 6) was injected into reservoirs.
chunks.chunk_summary: The controller module uses a programmable PCB with a microcontroller, DAC, and ADC for controlling voltage and sensing current; the device is assembled by connecting the ion pump and controller module via silver-coated pins.
chunks.authors: ["Houpu Li", "Hsin-ya Yang", "Narges Assefzadehbabai", "Prabhat Baniva", "Andrea Medina Lopez", "Anthony Gallegos", "Kan Zhu", "Tiffany Nguyen", "Cristian Hernandez", "Ksenia Zlobina", "Cynthia Recendez", "Hao-Chieh Hsieh", "Manyam Tebyan", "Hector Carreon", "John Selberg", "Le Luo", "Moysar A. Alom", "Aliaksei Narbonau", "Marco Rolando Camelen Min", "Athena M. Soulika", "Michael Levin", "Barge Jonathan", "Marcela Gomez", "Hish Zhao", "Mircea Teodorescu", "Roslyn Rivkah Isseroff"]

chunks.text: Ex vivo testing was conducted in PDMS wells with Steinberg solution. The device was connected to a potentiostat, and voltage patterns were controlled via computer. Voltage and current were recorded, and the solution was collected for analysis. Total charge was calculated by integrating current over time, and fluoxetine dose was calculated by HPLC-MS. Delivery efficiency (η) was calculated. HPLC-MS used a reversed-phase column. A standard curve was generated from known fluoxetine concentrations, and samples were analyzed to verify the fluoxetine peak. Peak area versus concentration was plotted and fitted to a calibration curve. Collected samples with unknown concentrations were analyzed, and their concentrations were calculated using the calibration curve.
chunks.chunk_summary: Ex vivo testing involved controlling voltage patterns and measuring current and fluoxetine dose using HPLC-MS with a calibration curve generated from known fluoxetine concentrations.
chunks.authors: ["Houpu Li", "Hsin-ya Yang", "Narges Assefzadehbabai", "Prabhat Baniva", "Andrea Medina Lopez", "Anthony Gallegos", "Kan Zhu", "Tiffany Nguyen", "Cristian Hernandez", "Ksenia Zlobina", "Cynthia Recendez", "Hao-Chieh Hsieh", "Manyam Tebyan", "Hector Carreon", "John Selberg", "Le Luo", "Moysar A. Alom", "Aliaksei Narbonau", "Marco Rolando Camelen Min", "Athena M. Soulika", "Michael Levin", "Barge Jonathan", "Marcela Gomez", "Hish Zhao", "Mircea Teodorescu", "Roslyn Rivkah Isseroff"]

chunks.text: The device was tested on C57BL/6J male mice with 6 mm circular wounds. Devices with fluoxetine (15 mice) or mock control (22 mice) were applied and secured with Tegaderm. The target fluoxetine dose was 100 nMol/day during the 6 h delivery program. On day 3, devices were removed, wound images were captured, and tissue was harvested. Wounds were excised, fixed in paraformaldehyde, and processed for FFPE histology. Tissues were dehydrated, paraffin-embedded, and cut into 5 µm sections. Re-epithelialization was assessed by H&E staining and brightfield imaging. Wound edges and epithelial ingrowth were measured, and percent re-epithelialization was calculated.
chunks.topic: In vivo testing and tissue analysis
chunks.chunk_summary: In vivo testing involved applying the device to mouse wounds, delivering 100 nMol/day of fluoxetine, and analyzing tissue sections for re-epithelialization using H&E staining.
chunks.authors: ["Houpu Li", "Hsin-ya Yang", "Narges Assefzadehbabai", "Prabhat Baniva", "Andrea Medina Lopez", "Anthony Gallegos", "Kan Zhu", "Tiffany Nguyen", "Cristian Hernandez", "Ksenia Zlobina", "Cynthia Recendez", "Hao-Chieh Hsieh", "Manyam Tebyan", "Hector Carreon", "John Selberg", "Le Luo", "Moysar A. Alom", "Aliaksei Narbonau", "Marco Rolando Camelen Min", "Athena M. Soulika", "Michael Levin", "Barge Jonathan", "Marcela Gomez", "Hish Zhao", "Mircea Teodorescu", "Roslyn Rivkah Isseroff"]

chunks.text: Macrophage staining was performed on full-thickness skin tissues. F4/80 (pan-macrophage marker), iNOS (M1 marker), and CD206 (M2 marker) antibodies were used. Primary and secondary antibody incubations were followed by DAPI counterstaining. Fluorescence images were acquired and processed. Macrophage subtypes were manually counted based on double-positive staining (F4/80+iNOS+ for M1, F4/80+CD206+ for M2). Fluoxetine and norfluoxetine levels in serum were measured using reverse-phase HPLC with UV detection and C18 PT-SPE. Serotonin quantitation was performed according to a published protocol. Statistical analysis used Excel, Scipy.stats, and Prism 9. Significance was assessed using Student's t-test (P <0.05). Correlation was evaluated using Pearson's coefficient (r2> 0.5 for strong correlation). Linear regression significance was evaluated using the Wald Test (P <0.05).
chunks.chunk_summary: Macrophage subtypes were identified using specific markers and counted; serum fluoxetine and norfluoxetine levels were measured using HPLC, and statistical analysis was performed using various software packages.
chunks.authors: ["Houpu Li", "Hsin-ya Yang", "Narges Assefzadehbabai", "Prabhat Baniva", "Andrea Medina Lopez", "Anthony Gallegos", "Kan Zhu", "Tiffany Nguyen", "Cristian Hernandez", "Ksenia Zlobina", "Cynthia Recendez", "Hao-Chieh Hsieh", "Manyam Tebyan", "Hector Carreon", "John Selberg", "Le Luo", "Moysar A. chunks.text: All animal experiments were approved by the IACUC at UC Davis. The protocol minimized pain and adhered to ethical guidelines. H.L. and H.Y. contributed equally. Several authors contributed to conceptualization, methodology, investigation, visualization, and supervision. H.L. and H.Y. wrote the original draft, and several authors reviewed and edited the final manuscript.  The data supporting the findings are available in the supplementary material. The authors acknowledge assistance from several individuals and institutions for mouse experiments, animal care, data analysis, and biocompatibility testing. Research was sponsored by DARPA. The authors declare no conflict of interest.

chunks.chunk_summary: The study adhered to ethical guidelines, multiple authors contributed to various aspects of the research, data is available in supplementary material, and there are no conflicts of interest.
